docs.title: Welcome to the Brickadia Community Wiki
docs.text: This wiki aims to be a basic collection of guides, tutorials and other information for the Brickadia community.

docs.title: Things to do
docs.text:
• Learn what Brickadia is
  • Check out cool guides like the Basics of Vehicles guide!
  • Learn how to host a dedicated Brickadia Windows, Linux, or Linux Omegga server!
  • Contribute something cool!
  • Check out the other pages here!
  • Take a look at other neat projects the Brickadia community has made!

docs.title: Contributer Guidelines
docs.text:
The following guidelines should be kept in mind when submitting changes:

  • Our audience is international based, so use clear and precise language, avoiding slang or acronyms without explanation.
  • Do not provide guides to facilitate illegal activity.
    • This includes but is not restricted to: Piracy, hacking, or otherwise exploiting software in an illegal manner.
  • Keep your writing tone non-biased and professional.
  • if you upload any images, please try to keep them below 2 Megabytes in size.

docs.title: Dedicated Servers
docs.text:
With the release of Brickadia on Steam, the dedicated server files are no longer gotten from the main brickadia website. Instead, these are now downloaded either directly from steam or anonymously from Steamcmd using appid 3017590.

Note that you will still need to supply the dedicated server a server hosting token by passing it the -token=yourtokenhere executable argument. Once the token is registered to the server for the first time, the -token argument can be omitted in future runs of the server executable.

Servers currently use udp port 7777. This can be changed if needed by supplying and modifying the -port=7777 argument to your desired port.

In some circumstances (such as hosting multiple servers on the same host) you may wish to change the location of the Dedicated Server's Saved directory (~/.config/Epic/Brickadia/ by default). This can be done using the -UserDir=PathToSavedDir argument.

docs.title: Dedicated Server Commands
docs.text:
These commands can be used directly in the terminal where the dedicated server is running.

Description Command grant self/player admin Chat.Command /GrantRole Admin [Your username here] Load map from mapfile name BR.World.Load "map name" Save map BR.World.Save Save map as name BR.World.SaveAs YourSaveNameHere Get Server status Server.Status

docs.title: How do I set up a dedicated server?
docs.text: See the server hosting guide.

docs.title: The server is running, but gets a "connection timed out" error when trying to connect!
docs.text:
Make sure that you have port forwarded UDP 7777. It is required for dedicated servers.

If you cannot port forward because you don't have admin credentials on your router or other blockers, you can host a server from the GUI in-game, which does not require port forwarding.

Port forwarding is a unique setup process for each router. You will probably find the best advice by searching YouTube for a video for port forwarding on your specific router.

Generally speaking, you will want to make a DHCP reservation for your computer so it always has the same IP address when it connects to your router. Otherwise, you will have to remake the port forward each time your router decides to give your computer a new IP address. Then, you can create the port forwarding entry.

Finally, ensure that your firewall is not blocking the incoming connections.

docs.title: Brickadia is crashing on launch / the server binary is crashing on launch.
docs.text: Make sure that your CPU supports AVX/AVX2. As a UE5 game, Brickadia explicitly requires this functionality on your CPU.

docs.title: Is there a list of console commands anywhere?
docs.text:
Not officially, but we are working to create one here.

You can also press ` (the key usually located above tab on your keyboard) to open the console in game to see auto-completions. Most of the commands available on the client are also available on the server console.

docs.title: How do I switch the base map?
docs.text:
The command is servertravel map where "map" is the map you want to switch to. For example, servertravel Studio will switch the server level to studio.

Note: As of writing, sometimes the servertravel can cause connected clients to crash. You can use travel to avoid this, but travel will disconnect all clients before switching the server level.

docs.title: What is the default server file location?
docs.text:
On Linux, if you installed with steamcmd and didn't run force_install_dir to change your installation directory, ~/.steam/steam/steamapps/common/BrickadiaServer

On Windows, if installed through the steam client, you can just right-click "Brickadia Server" -> properties -> installed files -> browse.

docs.title: Where are the server config files located?
docs.text:
On Linux, ~/.config/Epic/Brickadia/Saved/Config/LinuxServer/GameUserSettings.ini

On Windows, C:\Users\<yourusername>\AppData\Local\Brickadia\Saved\Config\WindowsServer\GameUserSettings.ini

  • A shortcut to get to this is pressing windows key + r to open run, then pasting %localappdata%\Brickadia\Saved\Config\WindowsServer and pressing ok.

docs.title: How do I add a custom world to my server?
docs.text:
1. Navigate to the worlds folder for your server:
    • On Linux, ~/.config/Epic/Brickadia/Saved/Worlds
    • On Windows, C:\Users\<yourusername>\AppData\Local\Brickadia\Saved\Worlds
  2. Drop the .brdb file in that directory.
  3. Run BR.World.Load "worldname" command without the file extension.
    • For example, if your world is called office world.brdb, you would run BR.World.Load "office world" in the console.

docs.title: I just restarted my server and all my bricks are missing!
docs.text:
Run BR.World.Load "worldname". If you do not remember your world name, you can look for it in the worlds folder for your server.

If there is no world in that directory, then you did not create a world save.

docs.title: I am running the server on Windows, and there isn't any console for me to type commands into?
docs.text: Either launch the server via steam, or set the flag -log to the BrickadiaServer-Win64-Shipping.exe.

docs.title: Brickadia Vehicle Basics
docs.text: This guide aims to teach the basics of how to make a simple vehicle to get around in within Brickadia.

docs.title: The Basic Car
docs.text:
To build a basic car you will need:

  • Plates -> 5x10f plate
  • Physics -> Bearing
  • Physics -> Wheel Joint
  • Mechanics -> Seat
  • Mechanics -> Wheel Engine
  • Physics -> Wheels > Off-Road A

  1. place the 5x10f plate in mid air a bit above the ground so we have room to build where the wheels will attach (hold alt to midair build)
  2. use the G key to choose the Selector Wand
  3. Click the 5x10f plate you placed earlier, and press U to make it a physics object
  4. hold G and choose the manipulator
  5. left click and drag the plate into the air, then right click to lock it in place. If you have done this correctly, it should look like this again
  6. choose the bearing, then place one on each corner of what will be the rear of the vehicle
  7. choose the Wheel Joint, then place those on the front of the vehicle, making sure that the arrows point downward
  8. select your Off-Road A wheel, then place them on all 4 points on front and back
  9. equip the manipulator, then left click the 5x10f plate to unfreeze it. your car body should fall to the ground.
  10. Select the Wheel Engine, and place it at the rear of the vehicle with the arrow pointing towards the front
  11. place the Seat at the front of the vehicle where you would like to sit
  12. equip the connector tool, then hover over the connection points over the engine until you see one called Player Input, and click it
  13. attach this point to the blue point on the Seat
  14. hover over the Wheel Engine, and now find the point called Control-Drive & Steer

  15. click this point, and connect it to the blue points on the front of the vehicle.

    Protip

    If you cannot find the blue connection points on the Wheel Joints on the front, you may need to detach your front wheels temporarily to wire up the connections.

  16. Hop in the front seat and drive!

You can experiment from here using the applicator on the Wheel Engine and the Wheel Joints to tweak settings on how the car operates as well as the distance the wheels stick out from the Wheel Joints. Have fun experimenting!

docs.title: Linux Dedicated Server Guide
docs.text:
So you want to use a linux server but dont know where to start? This guide is for you.

(Note for ARM server runners: You cannot currently use Box64 for ARM servers as the latest server version relies on features Box64 does not yet support)

docs.title: Prereqs (Steam Early Access Edition)
docs.text:
You will need:

  • a linux X86_64 VM with a recent CPU with 2-4 cores
  • at least 6 GB of RAM.
  • steamcmd
  • a copy of brickadia
  • ability to port forward udp port 7777
  • a public IP address

docs.title: Instructions
docs.text:
1. Log in to your linux VM and install steamcmd
    1. Note: if you prefer a distro agnostic method, just create a directory to hold steamcmd, cd into it, then run curl -sqL "https://steamcdn-a.akamaihd.net/client/installer/steamcmd_linux.tar.gz" | tar zxvf - to grab steamcmd. be sure to install the needed lib32gcc-s1 library from your package manager.
  2. Create a new folder somewhere to house the game files.
  3. Create a file called update-brickadia.sh, then run chmod +x update-brickadia.sh on it to make it executable.
  4. Open the file with your favorite editor and put the following: 
    #!/usr/bin/env bash
/path/to/steamcmd/steamcmd.sh +force_install_dir /your/install/directory +login anonymous +app_update 3017590
    • Be sure to replace /path/to/steamcmd/ with whatever path the steamcommand shell script lives at.
    • Also be sure to replace /your/install/directory with wherever you want the game files to live.
  5. Run the update-brickadia.sh script. It should install the brickadia server to the path you set above. You can re-use this script in the future to update the server when needed.
  6. Once the download finishes, you'll be dropped to the steamcmd shell, you can just type exit here.
  7. Inside of the install directory you set earlier, you will now have files. One of which is the folder Brickadia
  8. Go inside Brickadia/Binaries/Linux, and you should see the file BrickadiaServer-Linux-Shipping, this will be what we will use to launch the server in a bit.
  9. Go to https://brickadia.com/account and login, then generate a server hosting token and copy this somewhere.
  10. Back in the vm in the directory with the server launcher binary mentioned earlier, run the following command: ./BrickadiaServer-Linux-Shipping -log -port=7777 -token=yourTokenHere
  11. This will spin up the server, and after about 2 minutes it should be fully loaded.
  12. Connect to your dedicated server via manual connection in game. then go to Menu -> Edit Game and set up the server options and save them.
  13. In the linux environment, hit ctrl+c to stop the server.
  14. Run cd ~/.config/Epic/Brickadia/Saved/Config/LinuxServer to drop into the folder with the server config files.
  15. Edit GameUserSettings.ini to set your server name, password, etc until you are happy with it.
  16. Verify in your network port 7777 udp is port forwarded so that others can connect.
  17. Once the network is in place, go back to the directory with BrickadiaServer-Linux-Shipping in it.
  18. Since we have already registered the token to the game server, we can now just run the server with ./BrickadiaServer-Linux-Shipping -port=7777 -log going forward. Do this now.
  19. Open up Brickadia and connect to your server by hitting Join Game -> Connect Manually.
  20. You should now be connected, and the server is up!

docs.title: Enable Auto Save
docs.text:
1. In your server console, type BR.World.SaveAs savename (where savename is what you want the name of your save to be). This will create your save file for the server.
    • Note: If you do not run this command, the Auto Save won't function.
    • If you already created a save file for your server, you can skip this step.
  2. Connect to your server in game, press the escape key to open the menu -> edit game
  3. Click the advanced settings toggle at the top left of the menu
  4. Scroll to the bottom and enable Auto Save. You can also configure save interval and announcing of the saves.
  5. Whenever you restart your server, you will need to run BR.World.Load savename to have the server reload the save file.

docs.title: Omegga Brickadia Server Linux Setup Guide
docs.text:
Omegga is a project that wraps and extends the capabilities of a normal brickadia dedicated server by additionally providing the ability to run plugins as well as providing a nice web based UI to easily control and manage the brickadia server.

This guide aims to show how to do a basic install using Ubuntu Linunx. The extended install and troubleshooting guide can be found on the main project page

docs.title: Hardware
docs.text:
• at least 2 CPU cores
  • at least 6 GB of RAM.

docs.title: Software
docs.text:
• a Linux server (either a physical server or a Windows 11 machine running WSL will work) with Ubuntu installed
  • a user in the server who is NOT root.

docs.title: Windows WSL Specific Instructions
docs.text:
If you are running this via Windows 11 WSL2, you will need to add a config to the Ubuntu WSL config for you to be able to access the Web UI via localhost if you have not enabled this in the past.

  1. Open Powershell

  2. Add mirrored networking to the WSL system:

    "[wsl2]`nnetworkingMode=mirrored" | Add-Content -Encoding ASCII -Path "$env:USERPROFILE\.wslconfig"

  3. Turn off the WSL instance if it is running: wsl --shutdown Ubuntu

  4. Open the Ubuntu WSL app as normal, and it will start back up, then proceed with the install directions below.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
1. As mentioned above, verify you are not running as root and create a user if needed.

  2. Add the needed repositories for steamcmd:

    sudo add-apt-repository multiverse; sudo dpkg --add-architecture i386; sudo apt update

  3. Install steamcmd: sudo apt install steamcmd

  4. Install nvm:

    curl -o- https://raw.githubusercontent.com/nvm-sh/nvm/v0.40.3/install.sh | bash

  5. Activate nvm: . ~/.nvm/nvm.sh

  6. Install node v24: nvm install 24
  7. Install Omegga: npm i -g omegga
  8. Create a directory for the server to live in: mkdir omegga-server
  9. Navigate into the folder: cd omegga server
  10. Run omegga: omegga and it will generate server files in the directory you are currently in, and press Y to the steamcmd reference request
  11. The server will ask you whether you want to use username/password or hosting token authentication. Choose what you would prefer
  12. Once entered, the server will start, then it will show the address of where to access the webUI.

docs.title: Windows Dedicated Server Guide
docs.text: So you want to use a linux server but dont know where to start? This guide is for you.

docs.title: Prereqs (Steam Early Access Edition)
docs.text:
You will need:

  • a windows PC with at least of 8 GB of RAM (16 GB if you intend on using the same PC you play the game on)
  • a copy of Brickadia
  • ability to port forward udp port 7777
  • a public IP address

docs.title: Steam Dedicated Server Method
docs.text:
1. Sign in and open up Steam
  2. Go to your Library
  3. In the upper left corner, choose Games and Software, then checkmark Tools
  4. scroll down or search for Brickadia in your steam library. You should now see two items:
    • Brickadia
    • Brickadia Server
  5. Install the Brickadia Server item
  6. Go to https://brickadia.com/account and login, then generate a server hosting token. copy this somewhere
  7. Once the brickadia server is done installing, right click the Brickadia Server item, then choose Properties
  8. Be sure you have the General tab on the left selected
  9. Under LAUNCH OPTIONS, put -token=ReplaceMe, then change the ReplaceMe to be the token you copied several steps earlier. You now should have a similar entry as the one pictured below.
  10. Once you have entered this in, simply close the window using the X in the upper right corner
  11. Now launch the brickadia server
  12. If done correctly, you should have a window like the following:
  13. Now launch your normal Brickadia game on the computer you will be playing from
  14. Click Join Game then Manual Connect
    • If the brickadia server is on the same machine as the game, use the default 127.0.0.1 address to connect.
    • if the brickadia server is on a different machine, you will need to locate the IP address of the server, then fill out the IP address in the Manual Connect window.
  15. Open up the game menu (This is usually bound to the Esc key)
  16. Set your server info, description, password (if needed) and any other info. Then hit Save
  17. Back at your brickadia server terminal window, type exit to exit the server.
  18. Browse to %localappdata%\Brickadia\Saved\Config\WindowsServer
  19. In this directory, review your server settings within this file.
  20. If all settings look good, save the file.
  21. Verify now that you have port forwarded udp port 7777
  22. Start the Brickadia server again from Steam.

docs.title: Enable Auto Save
docs.text:
1. In your server console, type BR.World.SaveAs savename (where savename is what you want the name of your save to be). This will create your save file for the server.
    • Note: If you do not run this command, the Auto Save won't function.
    • If you already created a save file for your server, you can skip this step.
  2. Connect to your server in game, press the escape key to open the menu -> edit game
  3. Click the advanced settings toggle at the top left of the menu
  4. Scroll to the bottom and enable Auto Save. You can also configure save interval and announcing of the saves.
  5. Whenever you restart your server, you will need to run BR.World.Load savename to have the server reload the save file.
